subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: Ah, comprehension dawns! This is an absolute non-issue for you, and by extension for many others on this list! For those of us who have to backtrack once we re
messageBody:
Ah, comprehension dawns! This is an absolute non-issue for you, and by
extension for many others on this list!

For those of us who have to backtrack once we're halfway through a
word, realizing that we have to replace /3\/ with /Vr\/ in order to
correctly read the word--I guess we just have to acclimatize to the
notation.

Leaving the letters Utter and Roe unconnected in this context does no
harm, but it need not be encouraged generally.

Ted


On Nov 25, 2007 8:47 AM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
>
> > OK, so how should I rephrase it? Isn't LETTER /3\/, while 'arrest'
> > begins with /V/? (I was trying to avoid saying 'short U'.)
>
> To my ear, "arrest" doesn't begin with /V/, but with r-colored /@/,
> which is indeed /3\/.
>
> --
> And it was said that ever after, if any John Cowan
> man looked in that Stone, unless he had a cowan@...
> great strength of will to turn it to other http://ccil.org/~cowan
> purpose, he saw only two aged hands withering
> in flame. --"The Pyre of Denethor"
>
